authors: Bruno Sienkiewicz, Łukasz Neumann, Mateusz Modrzejewski
keywords: Concept-based interpretability, Music models, TCA V, Variational Autoencoder, Language model, MusicGen, Dataset
summary: ConceptCaps is a dataset of 23k music-caption-audio triplets with explicit labels from a 200-attribute taxonomy, designed to improve interpretability in music models by providing clean, well-separated examples for concept-based analyses.

title: Domain-Adaptation through Synthetic Data: Fine-Tuning Large Language Models for German Law
authors: Ali Hamza Bashir, Muhammad Rehan Khalid, Kostadin Cvejoski, Jana Birr, Jule Berghaus, Armin Berger, Sandra Halscheidt, Christian Temath, Rafet Sifa, David Berghaus
keywords: Large Language Models, Legal Question Answering, Synthetic Data, German Law, Domain Adaptation
summary: This paper presents a method for adapting large language models to German legal question answering using a novel synthetic data generation approach, demonstrating significant performance improvements over baseline models.

title: Paper2Rebuttal: A Multi-Agent Framework for Transparent Author Response Assistance
authors: Qianli Ma, Chang Guo, Zhiheng Tian, Siyu Wang, Jipeng Xiao, Yuanhao Yue, Zhipeng Zhang
keywords: multi-agent framework, rebuttal generation, evidence-centric planning, peer review process, AI, natural language processing
summary: Introducing REBUTTALAGENT, a multi-agent framework that reframes rebuttal generation as an evidence-centric planning task, ensuring responses are anchored in verifiable evidence, outperforming baselines in coverage, faithfulness, and strategic coherence.

filename: 2601.14172v1_Human Values in a Single Sentence Moral Presence H.pdf
title: Human Values in a Single Sentence: Moral Presence, Hierarchies, and Transformer Ensembles on the Schwartz Continuum
authors: Víctor Yeste, Paolo Rosso
keywords: sentence-level identification, Schwartz motivational continuum, human value detection, neural models, moral presence, hierarchy, multi-label classifier, DeBERTa-base, instruction-tuned LLMs, ensembles
summary: The study investigates sentence-level identification of 19 values in the Schwartz motivational continuum, focusing on the challenges of sparse moral cues and class imbalance, and compares various models and techniques for value detection.

title: A model of errors in transformers
authors: Suvrat Raju, Praneeth Netrapalli
keywords: LLMs, error rate, attention mechanism, task complexity, effective field theory, prompt construction
summary: The paper studies the error rate of large language models on deterministic tasks, deriving a two-parameter relationship between accuracy and task complexity, and empirically validating the model.

filename: 2601.14192v1_Toward Efficient Agents Memory Tool learning and P.pdf
title: Toward Efficient Agents: A Survey of Memory, Tool Learning, and Planning
authors: Xiaofang Yang, Lijun Li, Heng Zhou, Tong Zhu, Xiaoye Qu, Yuchen Fan, Qianshan Wei, Rui Ye, Li Kang, Yiran Qin, Zhiqiang Kou, Daizong Liu, Qi Li, Ning Ding, Siheng Chen, Jing Shao
keywords: Agents, Efficiency, Agent Memory, Tool Learning, Planning
summary: This paper investigates the efficiency of agentic systems from the perspectives of memory, tool learning, and planning, focusing on cost metrics like latency and tokens, and discusses high-level principles and benchmarks for efficiency.

title: Self-Proposed Interventions Enable Credit Assignment in LLM Reasoning
authors: Matthew Y. R. Yang, Hao Bai, Ian Wu, Gene Yang, Amrith Setlur, Aviral Kumar
keywords: large language models, reinforcement learning, credit assignment, intervention training, reasoning capabilities
summary: Intervention Training (InT) improves credit assignment in LLM reasoning by proposing targeted corrections to steer trajectories toward higher reward, enhancing accuracy significantly over base models.

title: MASCOT: Towards Multi-Agent Socio-Collaborative Companion Systems
authors: Yiyang Wang, Yiqiao Jin, Alex Cabral, Josiah Hester
keywords: Multi-agent systems, socio-collaborative companions, persona collapse, social sycophancy, bi-level optimization, RLAIF, meta-policy, psychological support, workplace domains, persona consistency, social contribution
summary: MASCOT is a framework for multi-agent socio-collaborative companions, addressing persona collapse and social sycophancy through a bi-level optimization strategy, achieving significant improvements in persona consistency and social contribution.

title: KAGE-Bench: Fast Known-Axis Visual Generalization Evaluation for Reinforcement Learning
authors: Egor Cherepannov, Daniil Zelezetsky, Alexey K. Kovalev, Aleksandr I. Panov
keywords: Reinforcement Learning, Visual Generalization, Pixel-based Agents, Distribution Shift, JAX, PPO-CNN, Benchmarking
summary: KAGE-Bench introduces a JAX-native 2D platformer to evaluate visual generalization in reinforcement learning, isolating visual shifts and enabling fast, reproducible experiments.

title: Q-LEARNING WITH ADJOINT MATCHING
authors: Qiyang Li, Sergey Levine
keywords: Q-learning, Adjoint Matching, TD-based reinforcement learning, continuous-action RL, diffusion policy, flow-matching policy, temporal-difference, critic, policy optimization
summary: We propose Q-learning with Adjoint Matching (QAM), a novel TD-based reinforcement learning algorithm that efficiently optimizes expressive diffusion or flow-matching policies with respect to a parameterized Q-function, leveraging adjoint matching to avoid unstable backpropagation.

summary: This paper explores the opportunities for applying AI and ML techniques to the Rubin LSST project, focusing on enhancing data analysis and scientific discovery.

title: APEX–Agents: A Benchmark for Assessing AI Agents in Professional Services
authors: Bertie Vidgen, Austin Mann, Abby Fennelly, John Wright, Stanly, Lucas Rothman, Marco Burstein, Julien Benchek, David Ostrofsky, Anirudh Ravichandran, Debnil Sur, Neel Venugopal, Alannah Hsia, Isaac Robinson, Calix Huang, Olivia Varones, Daniyal Khan, Michael Haines, Zach Richards, Chirag Mahapatra, Brendan Foody, Osvald Nitski

title: VideoMaMa: Mask-Guided Video Matting via Generative Prior
authors: Sangbeom Lim, Seoung Wug Oh, Jiahui Huang, Heeji Yoon, Seungryong Kim, Joon-Young Lee
keywords: video matting, diffusion models, generative priors, segmentation masks, alpha mattes, pseudo-labeling, large-scale datasets
summary: VideoMaMa is a diffusion-based model that converts coarse segmentation masks into pixel-accurate alpha mattes, demonstrating strong zero-shot generalization to real-world footage and enabling scalable video matting research.
